sub_topic: Calculation of the Bohr radius in hydrogen atom
message_1: What is the Bohr radius for a hydrogen atom when its electron is in the n=1 energy level? Calculate the value using the known constants and formulas of atomic physics.
message_2:
The Bohr radius for a hydrogen atom when its electron is in the n=1 energy level can be calculated using the following formula:

a₀ = (4πε₀ħ²) / (m_e * e²)

where:
a₀ is the Bohr radius,
ε₀ is the vacuum permittivity (8.854 x 10^(-12) C²/Nm²),
ħ is the reduced Planck constant (1.054 x 10^(-34) Js),
m_e is the electron mass (9.109 x 10^(-31) kg), and
e is the elementary charge (1.602 x 10^(-19) C).

Plugging in the values:

a₀ = (4π * 8.854 x 10^(-12) * (1.054 x 10^(-34))^2) / (9.109 x 10^(-31) * (1.602 x 10^(-19))^2)

a₀ ≈ 5.291 x 10^(-11) m

So, the Bohr radius for a hydrogen atom when its electron is in the n=1 energy level is approximately 5.291 x 10^(-11) meters.
